discussion.content:
Was pretty confident the answers were wrong before testing. Tested, and turns out I was correct. The outbound firewall rule is, by default, allowed on all network profile types. 99% of the time, the problem is with the inbound rule, which is NOT allowed on any profiles by default. The only time the outbound rule changes behavior is when it's set to a block rule and enabled. 

So for the answers, it will depend upon if (1) the firewall rules match the network type of the device and (2) whether there are any explicit deny output ICMPv4 request block rules. We aren't told of any block rules and, given the firewall rules, it would SEEM to be safe to assume that the Inbound rules match the network type. If we do that, since computer one only accepts ICMPv4 requests from its private network and computer 2 accepts them from its public network, computer 3 can be pinged from both of them. So the answer should be, 

First box: Computer 2 and Computer 3
Second Box: Computer 1 and Computer 3

The problem with the question is that we aren't given enough information to make a decent informative decision.

Computer2 can ping only Computer3 because the ICMPv4 rule is Allow in ALL
Computer1 has ICMPv4 for Private only
answer and explanation is really weird and wrong.

comments.content:
I've seen quite some weird and wrong answers, but this one seems to be correct.
Computer 1 and computer 2 are domain-joined, so the domain firewall profile applies on these computers.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
Which Windows 10 computers can you ping successfully from Computer1 and Computer2? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Computer3 only.
Computer1 and Computer2 are domain joined so both will be using the Domain profile. The firewall rules on Computer1 allow outbound ICMP on all profiles so outbound ICMP will be allowed on the Domain profile.
The firewall rules on Computer2 allow inbound ICMP on the Public profile only, so it will be blocked on the domain profile. Therefore, Computer2 cannot be pinged.
The firewall rules on Computer3 allow inbound ICMP on all profiles. Therefore, Computer3 will not block the inbound pings.
Box 2: No Windows 10 computers.
The firewall rules on Computer2 allow outbound ICMP on the Private profile only, so it will be blocked on the domain profile. Therefore, Computer2 cannot ping any computers.

Box 1: Yes -
User1 already has full control access through membership of Group1. Therefore, User1 can write to the file.

Box 2: No -
The planned changes will grant User2 full control access to the file. However, User2 is a member of Group2 which has Deny/Write access. The Deny permission will always take precedence. Therefore, User2 will not be able to write to the file.

Box 3: No -
The planned changes will grant User3 full control access to the folder. That permission will be inherited by the file. However, User3 is a member of Group2 which has Deny/Write access. The Deny permission will always take precedence. Therefore, User3 will not be able to write to the file.
questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You implement the planned changes for Computer1.
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Yes, Yes, No

User1 has full access explicit permissions on file
User2 has full access explicit permissions on file. Explicit allow permissions wins over inherited deny permissions
User3 has full access inherited permissions on folder. Inherited deny permissions wins over inherited allow permissions, so user cannot write to file

comments.content: I agree with your reasoning. Can anyone back this up?
I’m not sure User 2 is true. User 2 has explicit deny write permission which takes precedence

It doesn't seem like he has explicitly deny write permission to me. All of the "old" permissions say "inherited from Folder1", so none of them are explicit for the file. As such, User2 should have write permission now.
It says inheritance is disabled. Aren't all of these permissions that are listed, explicit permissions?

Yes, No, No.

What user lapobs says is key and he is right that as a result of disabling the inheritance the permissions are explicit.

The table provided in the questions speaks of inheritance and seems in contradiction but we must presume that this is how the permissions were set and that inheritance was disabled afterwards. In that case a GUI asks if the permissions should be converted to explicit permissions on the object or removed altogether. Again, we must presume they have been converted to explicit permissions. 

So for User2, there is an explicit Group2 Write Deny which prevails over any allows. Similar reasoning for User3 which is a member of Group2. The answer is therefore: Yes No No 

The proximity rule raised by user LArrikin27 (inherited versus explicit) is important to know but does not come into play here since the permissions have all been converted to explicit.

Rawizz 2023-07-28

discussion.content: Correction Y-Y-N is correct. User2 has Full control on the report file which will win over the inherited deny right
Y-N-N is correct

For me it is all YES
Explicit permissions win the inherited (from a group) permissions
https://www.ntfs.com/ntfs-permissions-precedence.htm

Sorry, my bad !
Just tested it, the correct answers are Y,Y,N

questions.question_text:
You need to recommend a solution to configure the employee VPN connections.
What should you include in the recommendation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Intune is a Microsoft 365 service and the contractors do NOT have access. CMAK is a configuration file to help assist the contractor.

Selected Answer: C
Need to provide the users with a file, which you can create using CMAK.

Selected Answer: D
I have no doubt it is D.

The distribution process is way more effective with Intune. CMAK would be an answer if we would not have 500 employees to deal.

“When employees attempt to connect to the network from their home computer, they often cannot establish a VPN connection because of misconfigured VPN settings.”

“Provide employees with a configuration file to configure their VPN connection.”

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/remote/remote-access/vpn/always-on-vpn/deploy/vpn-deploy-client-vpn-connections#create-the-always-on-vpn-configuration-policy

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/configuration/vpn-settings-configure

Very good knowledge about this subject: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5eZNwYB6DZ4

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.
Why C is wrong:
W10 does not work with CMAK
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/troubleshoot/windows-client/networking/cmak-based-vpn-doesnt-work

comments.content:
[Edit] nvm, they actually tell you to reinstall it.
So C could be correct???¿¿¿

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I agree that it should be CMAK since it produces a configuration file but I am not sure whether it is supported since Windows 10 is not stated here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/it-pro/windows-server-2012-R2-and-2012/hh831675(v=ws.11)

For this reason, I would go with Intune
C - Correct
or maybe I am wrong and yo can tell the end users to run the install package from a network drive. I can't see walking around with a USB drive.
minimum amount of administrative effort is the key here. CMAK creates, Intune would send it to the machines. So D is correct. Who is going around to 100 laptops and loading a file on each one?
Answer C - Provide employees with a configuration file to configure their VPN connection. - With Intune you can not export a config file.

comments.content: I agree the answer is C

discussion.content:
The technical requirements say, "Provide employees with a configuration file to configure their VPN connection." Will Intune provide a configuration file? The correct answer may be C, Connection Manager Administration Kit (CMAK). According to Microsoft, "Running the CMAK wizard produces a connection profile that is stored in an executable file. Running that file on a client computer equips that computer with everything needed to establish the network connection that you designed."

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/it-pro/windows-server-2008-R2-and-2008/cc752995(v=ws.11)?redirectedfrom=MSDN

"An employee has a computer named Computer11. Computer11 has a hardware failure that prevents the computer from connecting to the network."

How do you connect remotely to a PC that is not connecting to network :)

Answer is A - Technical requirements "Ensure that the service desk uses Quick Assist to take remote control of an employee's desktop during support calls" You have to provide a code to the user to connect to Quick assited

questions.question_text:
You need to take remote control of an employee's computer to troubleshoot an issue.
What should you send to the employee to initiate a remote session?

You need to meet the technical requirement for User6.
What should you do?

discussion.content: User6 is a member of a group that has 'Deny' rights to remote desktop. First step is to remove User6 from the group.

comments.content: I think the more restrictive rule would win here. So they would still be denied access.
Tested. RDP is block so answer B is correct

Not right, User6 is member of Group2 and Group3.
Group2 - Deny access to this computer from the network
Group3 - Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services.
But I think it can block RDP. You are right.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Based on the information in the question, User6 will not be able to connect remotely via Remote Desktop. One of two measures is required for this to happen:

1 - Remove Group2 from Deny access to this computer from the network policy (LGPO or GPO).
2 - Remove User6 from Group2 in the domain.

An extra step should still occur which would be any of the alternatives A, C and D.

It is mandatory that User6 be part of the Remote Desktop User group (local or domain). Or, as a last resort, breaking the principle of least privilege, add User6 to the administrators group (local or domain).

So the answer is B. Then it goes to the extra step.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct ! Deny Access to the computer from the network includes RDP, SMB etc... So user MUST be removed form group 2 in order to connect via RDP.
Correct Answer. Deny over Access.

User6 needs to be added to the Remote Desktop Users group on Computer2.

"Note that Deny access to this computer from the network denies only remote SMB connections; it does not prevent interactive logon or RDP access."
https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/130208/why-does-disa-stig-recommend-deny-access-to-this-computer-from-the-network-for

"Deny log on through Remote Desktop Services" would prevent a user from logging in through Remote Desktop.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/security-policy-settings/deny-log-on-through-remote-desktop-services

choices.C: Add User6 to the Remote Desktop Users group on Computer2.
choices.A: Add User6 to the Remote Desktop Users group in the domain.
choices.D: And User6 to the Administrators group on Computer2.
choices.B: Remove User6 from Group2 in the domain.
